title: 111_hr4906
content: The Act may be cited as the "ARPA-E Reauthorization Act of 2010" and includes amendments to ARPA-E. Section 5012 of the America COMPETES Act is amended to include promoting the commercial application of advanced energy technologies and research and development of advanced manufacturing processes for novel energy technologies. The America COMPETES Act is amended to include promoting the commercial application of advanced energy technologies and research and development of advanced manufacturing processes for novel energy technologies. The Director shall initiate and execute awards in the form of grants, contracts, cooperative agreements, cash prizes, and other transactions. The Director of ARPA-E shall establish a qualified staff separate from the rest of the Department to carry out its responsibilities. This includes legal counsel, contracting personnel, and program directors with expertise. The Director of ARPA-E shall establish a qualified staff separate from the rest of the Department to carry out its responsibilities, including identifying innovative cost-sharing arrangements and mechanisms for ARPA-E projects. The Director of ARPA-E shall establish mechanisms for commercial application of successful energy technology development projects, including partnerships with commercial entities. The Director of ARPA-E can select early career and senior personnel as fellows for up to two years to support program managers, explore new program areas, and assist in strategic vision creation. The Director of ARPA-E can select personnel as fellows to support program managers, explore new program areas, and assist in strategic vision creation. Additionally, the Director is responsible for preparing energy technology and economic analyses, seeking opportunities to partner with Federal agencies for technology demonstrations funded through ARPA-E. The Director of ARPA-E is authorized to organize events that bring together stakeholders to showcase projects, discuss commercial applications of energy technologies, and promote collaboration with government-sponsored research programs. In subsection (m)(1), the Director can now authorize funding for up to 6 years instead of 4 years. Section (m)(2)(B) allows for lessons learned from ARPA-E to be applied to other Department of Energy programs. Subsection (o)(2) authorizes $300,000,000 for the Director to deposit in the Fund for fiscal year 2011. The limitation for funding under subsection (o) is set at increasing amounts from $300,000,000 for fiscal year 2011 to such sums as necessary for each of fiscal years 2016 through 2020. Additionally, subsection (o) is amended to strike paragraph (4) and redesignate paragraph (5) as paragraph (4).
